title: Glynllifon Country Park Walking Route

images.title: Stephen Elwyn RODDICK / Ornamental Bridges, Glynllifon Country Park.
images.caption: Ornamental Bridges, Glynllifon Country Park. I took this photograph in late November 2004 with a small Nikon digital camera, using a tree trunk to steady the camera during exposure because of the low light levels. The view is eastwards in a wood named "Gwern-y-felin."

images.title: Dot Potter / Weir at Glynllifon Country Park
images.caption: Weir at Glynllifon Country Park. The weir runs behind the workshops on the path leading through the park.

images.title: Dot Potter / River at Plas Glynllifon
images.caption: River at Plas Glynllifon. Running in front of the mansion house in the country park, the river cuts through the park.

images.title: Alan Fryer / Parc Glynllifon
images.caption: Parc Glynllifon. The entrance to the estate and country park through the workshop complex. At the time the picture was taken the annual three-day Craft and Food Fair had just opened

images.title: Eric Jones / A series of ornamental waterfalls on Afon Llifon
images.caption: A series of ornamental waterfalls on Afon Llifon

images.title: Eric Jones / The Bettws woodland with the Glynllifon workshops in the background
images.caption: The Bettws woodland with the Glynllifon workshops in the background

images.title: Eric Jones / The main drive towards the front of Plas Glynllifon house
images.caption: The main drive towards the front of Plas Glynllifon house. This drive follows the south bank of the Llifon and runs through ornamental gardens and woodlands.

images.title: Eric Jones / Plas Glynllifon
images.caption: Plas Glynllifon. This was the seat of the Newborough family until 1948 when death duties forced them to sell the estate. In 1954 an agricultural college was established in the parkland, which today, in an expanded form, is known as Coleg Meirion-Dwyfor. The main house was built in the 1830s by the 3rd Lord Newborough.

description: Explore the woodland, gardens, parkland and riverside in this beautiful country park in Gwynedd. The park and gardens are Grade One listed and home to some of the rarest flora and fauna in the Wales. Glynllifon contains many lovely walking trails including one through woodland and along the River Llifon with follies and sculptures along the way. There is also a cafe and a maze and exhibits such as steam power pistons restored by Fred Dibnah. The park sits next to the Lon Eifion Cycle/Walk Route which runs along a disused railway line. If you'd like to extend your walking in the area then this is a good option. The surfaced path has great views of the Welsh Highland Railway and Snowdonia National Park.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The on site Black Cat Cafe is the perfect place for refreshments after your walk. They have a good menu and some outdoor seating with nice views.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The park is a lovely place to walk the dog and you'll probably see plenty of other owners on your outing. You are advised to please keep them on leads. The cafe mentioned above is also dog friendly.

display_address: A499, Bethesda-bach, Llandwrog, Y Groeslon, Gwynedd, Cymru / Wales, LL54 5DY, United Kingdom
